text.p: These are the leading stories in the Egyptian press on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Hebron agreement signed by Palestinian President Yasser Arafat and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. Mubarak said that Egypt's proposal on delaying redeployment opened the way for the agreement.

- In an interview with the Lebanese newspaper al-Nahar, Mubarak said that war was impossible but terrorism was more dangerous and worse. He will visit the "New Delta" every two months to monitor what has been accomplished.
- Mubarak received the deputy prime minister of Luxembourg, Jacques Poos.
- 38 people were killed and 29 injured when a bus fell in the Nile from Rod al-Farag bridge.
- The Social Fund for Development has created 360,000 jobs in three years through investing 1.8 billion pounds ($530 million).

- The public prosecutor has referred 32 people to the State Security Court in the cases of unsecured loans made by Dakahleya Commercial Bank and Nile Bank. The defendants in the cases include the bank chairmen, Tawfik Abdu Ismail of Dakahleya Bank and Issa el-Ayouty of Nile Bank, and some members of parliament whose immunity has been lifted. The charges against them include deliberate abuse of public monies in that the chairmen and bank officials made unsecured loans amounting to 1.014 billion pounds. By June 1996, they had paid back 402 million pounds.
- Hebron agreement signed. Mubarak said that Egyptian proposals helped conclude the deal.

- President Mubarak received a telephone call yesterday evening from King Hussein of Jordan on the Hebron agreement. Mubarak called Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat on the latest developments in the negotiations.
- At last the Hebron agreement has been signed.

- The ministerial privatisation committee has agreed to standardise the rules for selling land and real estate belonging to public-sector companies. The aim is to ensure that the sale is transparent. Public Enterprise Minister Atef Obeid said the proceeds from such sales would go to a Central Bank account to be spent on restructuring public-sector companies and on early retirement for workers.
